Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Geometric Methods in Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Conference on Geometric Methods in Representation Theory will be held at the University of Missouri-Columbia on November 23-25, 2013. The conference brings together experts working on geometric methods in the representation theory of finite dimensional algebras and related topics, and beginning researchers in this area, such as graduate students and postdocs. There will be expository and other research talks on topics such as: semi-invariants for bound quivers; moduli problems for finite-dimensional algebras; degenerations of modules and the geometry of orbit closures in module varieties; universal deformation rings and their connection to moduli spaces; cluster algebras. This conference will help strengthen and advance the interaction of geometry and representation theory.

One of the main objectives of the Conference on Geometric Methods in Representation Theory is to introduce beginning researchers in representation theory to the power of geometric methods. These methods have become more and more fundamental in many areas of mathematics, and in particular in the representation theory of finite dimensional algebras. The key note speaker for this conference will be Jerzy Weyman who will give two one-hour lectures which will be accessible to graduate students and postdocs. There will also be several expository lectures given by well-known experts. The remainder of the lectures will be research talks given by both senior and junior mathematicians. This will include several talks given by graduate students and postdocs related to their theses. The conference will provide an inviting atmosphere in which new collaborations can be formed and young researchers have the possibility to learn about cutting-edge geometric methods in representation theory. Moreover, the conference will enable junior representation theorists to present their work and interact with the broader community, which are crucial activities in the pre-employment season in the fall. More information about the Conference on Geometric Methods in Representation Theory at the University of Missouri-Columbia can be found at http://www.math.uiowa.edu/~fbleher/CGMRT2013.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2013 Conference on Geometric Methods in Representation Theory was held at the University of Missouri-Columbia on November 23-25 with participants from 18 different institutions. The keynote speaker for this conference was Jerzy Weyman (University of Connecticut) who gave two one-hour lectures, emphasizing geometric methods, where these lectures were accessible to graduate students. In addition to the keynote lectures, there were two 50-minute expository talks, six 30-minute regular talk, and twelve 20-minute talks by graduate students, postdocs and early career mathematicians. The conference webpage (http://homepage.math.uiowa.edu/~fbleher/CGMRT2013.html) gives summaries of the talks, and videos of the keynote and expository talks.

This conference enabled junior representation theorists to learn about the power of geometric methods. In addition, it provided an inviting atmosphere in which young researchers had the opportunity to present their work and interact with the broader community. This, in particular, allowed the younger participants to learn about employment opportunities and network with other people. Moreover, this conference gave a unique opportunity to more senior mathematicians to learn about cutting-edge geometric methods in representation theory and to experts in this area to report about their work at a conference dedicated to their expertise.

The NSF funding allowed graduate students, postdocs, and early career mathematicians to attend the conference.
